case_vignette: A 65-year-old African American man    presents to dermatology clinic for multiple non-painful, non-itchy brown spots on the face. He notes they started developing    when he    was 42 years old, and they have incre ased in number and    size. Sometimes he tries to remove them  with a needle, but they will bleed.   Physical exam reveals multiple dark, flat topped o   void papules, and few pedunculated brown-black  papules on the bilateral zygomatic cheeks.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
Hello! I have multiple non-painful, non-itchy brown spots on my face that have been increasing in number and size since they first appeared.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I am a 65-year-old man.
Have you had any recent exposure to the sun or tanning beds?
No, I have not mentioned any recent exposure to the sun or tanning beds.

I haven't noticed any changes in the spots after exposure to sunlight.
Do you have a family history of similar skin conditions or skin cancer?
I haven't mentioned any family history of similar skin conditions or skin cancer.
Have you experienced any other changes on your skin or general health issues recently?
No, I haven't mentioned any other changes on my skin or general health issues recently.
Final Diagnosis: Seborrheic keratosis.
